page.title: 07LANDSCAPE
page.content:
The whole western,northern and southern part of the area is typified by low,inhospitable moorland on the flat tops of ridges that form the hills between the Peak District and Sheffield. There is nowadays no natural tree cover of significance but conifers, birches,dwarf oaks and beech grow in the gullies or {cloughs}that small streams flow down, draining the moors.
Enclosure of the land is by dry stone walling, but it is being replaced by fencing as the walls collapse. Many stone sheep folds are still visible. Until the 1940s quarrying for clay and building or roofing stone was an important industry and the moor is littered with the workings a large example being on the N.W.corner of the area.
